author: ReloadTheLegendary

text:
Yes, it was quite an amazing nostalgic discovery ;)
I was stuck forever in this game first time playing because I could not figure out one crucial part because of the language barrier (though even my English was sub-par back then, since it is not my native language). I think I got stuck right before going to Omnitopia. I just walked around aimlessly whenever I played, just gathering stuff :D

author: Allen Andrews

text: @zunnoab Thraxx is the name of the boss pictured on the box cover art, the first major boss in the game.
author: JooshMate

text: @dx619hey Oh and that's one of the early bosses in the game on the box art. It's been over a decade since I played it though so I don't remember the name of it.
author: zunnoab

text: @dx619hey Yeah the SNES' music chip was amazing for its time. Its musical capabilities for sure were way ahead of its graphics.
author: zunnoab

text:
... the SNES is capable of that ambience? It sounds so real.

And what the hell is that thing on the boxart? Seriously, what the hell is going on with it. It's such a confusing, but oddly compelling mix of disproportion, symmetry, shading, and goddamn it's creepy. Who drew that?
author: dx619hey

text: I remember playing this when i was like 6 years old, i couldn't get past the first stage of the game, the jungle. I replayed it once i was like 16, and had a decent knowledge of the English language and i managed to finally beat it. Great game if you ask me.

text:
@ilovecardj I don't know, I enjoyed them both about equally. Secret of Mana had a more moving storyline and was longer, but this game was very fun to play through and did a good job of creating atmosphere(partly because of the music).

I play them both every year :)
